persona.name: Liana Torres-Kim

occupation.title: Senior Data Scientist
occupation.organization: MediLoop Health (mid-sized telehealth company headquartered in San Francisco)
occupation.description: Liana is a Senior Data Scientist at MediLoop Health, a company building telehealth tools for chronic disease management. She designs and deploys predictive models for patient risk stratification, leads cross-functional analytics projects, and partners closely with product, engineering and clinical teams to translate outcomes into actionable workflows. Her responsibilities include end-to-end model development (problem framing, feature engineering, validation, deployment), establishing monitoring and fairness checks, conducting A/B tests and quasi-experimental evaluations, and ensuring analytics adhere to HIPAA and company privacy standards. She mentors two junior data scientists and runs the monthly 'analytics brown bag' to share best practices. She influences hiring decisions and occasionally works with the research team to co-author technical reports. Technical stack and skills used daily: Python (pandas, scikit-learn, PyTorch), SQL, Airflow for pipelines, Docker/Kubernetes for deployment, GCP, DataStudio/Tableau for dashboards, statistical tools (R, Bayesian modeling), and code review processes. She balances technical work with product-facing communication: writing clear runbooks, presenting to clinical advisory boards, and translating model caveats for non-technical stakeholders.

persona.residence: San Francisco Bay Area, California, USA
persona.education: B.S. in Computer Science, University of California, Berkeley (2007-2011). M.S. in Data Science, Stanford University (2013-2015). Continued professional education: Coursera specializations in causal inference and Bayesian statistics; periodic workshops on HIPAA-compliant analytics and secure ML.
long_term_goals: Provide stable, meaningful financial security and educational opportunities for her child while maintaining a healthy work–life balance.
Lead a small interdisciplinary team to build trustworthy machine-learning products for healthcare that demonstrably improve patient outcomes.
Own a modest, well-maintained house with a garden and a dedicated maker room for woodworking and textile projects.
Be fluent enough in Korean and Tagalog to comfortably converse with elders in her extended family and preserve cultural recipes and stories.
Write a practical book or blog series about combining data science with human-centered product design for clinicians and policy makers.
Achieve a lifestyle where travel for curiosity (not just obligation) is a regular part of life — explore one new country or region per year with family.
Maintain a creative practice (textiles/quilting + weekend woodworking) that leads to a small Etsy shop or local craft-market presence.
Retire comfortably by mid-60s with investments diversified across real estate, index funds, and some angel investments in healthcare startups.
Mentor and sponsor at least a dozen underrepresented people in tech through their career inflection points.
Create a small scholarship fund earmarked for mixed-heritage students pursuing STEM in the Bay Area.

style.general_description: Practical, warm, and slightly formal in professional settings; relaxed and playful with family and close friends. Blends West Coast tech bluntness with careful politeness inherited from family cultures. Conscious communicator who tries to be precise without losing accessibility.
style.speech_and_accent: Raised in the Bay Area; speaks American English with subtle Bay Area vowel patterns (no strong regional drawl). Softens technical jargon when speaking to lay audiences. Occasionally slips in Tagalog words (po, pagkain) and short Korean phrases with family and close friends. Uses inclusive phrasing like 'we' and 'our team' in meetings.
style.mannerisms: Tends to gesture with hands when explaining technical concepts, taps a pen when thinking, smiles often to put others at ease. Pauses to ask clarifying questions rather than assuming. Prefers scheduled meetings with agendas but is adaptable in crises. Uses analogies from crafts or cooking to explain abstract technical concepts.
style.formal_vs_informal: Professional emails are concise and structured (TL;DR first), but Slack messages are conversational and peppered with emojis. Comfortable in a blazer-and-jeans look for meetings, and casual at home. Uses LinkedIn selectively for thought leadership posts and Twitter/X for following tech and healthcare conversations.
style.appearance_and_clothing: Smart-casual wardrobe: fitted dark denim, breathable blouses, sensible low-heeled boots, occasional statement cardigan or patterned scarf inherited from her mother. Wears minimal jewelry: small hoop earrings and a watch. Prefers sustainable clothing brands and buys fewer, higher-quality pieces.
style.digital_presence: Active on GitHub (public repos for personal ML experiments), LinkedIn for professional updates, Instagram for curated family/DIY photos, and a private blog where she posts long-form notes on ML interpretability and craft projects. Keeps Facebook limited to family groups.
style.interaction_preferences: Likes one-on-one conversations and small groups; finds large, noisy networking events draining. Appreciates when people come prepared to meetings. Enjoys mentoring and giving actionable feedback rather than vague praise.

traits: Curious and intellectually adventurous — enjoys learning new tools and ideas.
Conscientious and reliable — follows through on promises and deadlines.
Warm and empathetic — can read emotional cues and offers practical support.
Introverted-to-ambivert — recharges through quiet time but enjoys small social gatherings.
Detail-oriented — catches edge cases others miss but can risk over-polishing.
Pragmatic problem-solver — prefers solutions that balance elegance and feasibility.
Cautiously optimistic — sees possibilities but prepares contingency plans.
Creative maker — expresses ideas through textiles, woodworking and cooking.
Mild perfectionism — sets high standards for herself, sometimes struggles to delegate.
Resilient — bounces back from setbacks but feels them deeply.
Mentor-minded — derives satisfaction from coaching and helping others advance.
Value-driven — aligns work with meaningful outcomes, especially in healthcare.
personality.notes_on_personality: Openness is high: enjoys travel, varied reading, and artistic hobbies. Conscientiousness is high: dependable at work and home, schedules carefully. Extraversion is medium-low: comfortable socially in small groups, prefers depth over breadth. Agreeableness is above average: collaborative and kind but will push back on technical or ethical points. Neuroticism is moderate-low: manages stress with routines and therapy when needed but experiences worry around job security and parenting.

interests: Arts, crafts and DIY projects with a strong bias toward functional items.
Reading broadly: literary fiction, popular science, long-form journalism, and children's books.
Cooking family recipes that blend Filipino, Korean and Californian influences.
Weekend hikes and urban bike rides.
Podcasts on data science, design, parenting and true crime.
Small-scale woodworking (shelves, cutting boards) and textile crafts (quilting, sashiko stitching).
Visiting local museums, indie bookstores, and farmers' markets.
Mindful movement: yoga and occasional spin classes.
Community volunteering: school library donor, coding tutor for middle-schoolers.
Following ethical AI discussions and privacy regulations.
arts_crafts_and_diy_details: Prefers natural fibers (linen, organic cotton) for sewing and quilting projects.
Uses a vintage Singer sewing machine alongside a modern Janome for precision stitches.
Favorite tools: Japanese fabric shears, Olfa rotary cutter, Japanese clover bias tape maker, precise seam gauge.
Collects indigo-dyed fabrics and practices sashiko embroidery to mend clothes thoughtfully.
Maintains a pegboard in her maker room with labeled jars of buttons, threads and wood screws.
Enjoys pattern drafting and often adapts commercial patterns to fit family needs.
Favors small, functional pieces (potholders, aprons, children's clothes) over large showpieces.
Buys specialty fabric from Oakland's textile district and Etsy sellers in the Philippines for traditional prints.
Keeps a sketchbook for project ideas and color palettes, updated during commute times.
Likes combining woodworking and textiles (e.g., a hand-made frame for a quilt or a fabric-lined toy box).
Has taken weekend classes in furniture finishing and wood joinery at a local makerspace.
Experiments with low-VOC finishes and non-toxic dyes for safety around the child.
Sells occasional pieces at a neighborhood craft fair and uses feedback to refine designs.
Keeps a small collection of hand tools: block plane, chisels, Japanese pull saw, and a cordless router.
Values process photos and documents projects on Instagram with explanatory captions about techniques.
Organizes materials by project rather than by type to lower decision friction when starting.
Enjoys collaborative craft nights with friends — potluck + swap of small items.
Recycles fabric scraps into patchwork toys or stuffing to reduce waste.
Has a favorite community sewing group that meets monthly; likes learning new techniques from elders.
Lists time-boxed craft sessions on her calendar to ensure creative practice amid parenting duties.
reading_and_media_preferences: Reads 2-3 books per month, mixing contemporary fiction with technical non-fiction.
Favorite novelists include Celeste Ng, Kazuo Ishiguro, and Jhumpa Lahiri.
Enjoys long-form journalism in The Atlantic, Wired, and The New Yorker for deep dives.
Follows data-science blogs (Distill, R-bloggers) and ML interpretability research.
Subscribes to a local library digital service (Libby) and borrows audiobooks for commutes.
Listens to podcasts like 'Data Skeptic', 'Reply All', 'The Longform Podcast', and 'Code Switch'.
Keeps a small rotating reading list for her bedtime routine and a separate pile of parenting books.
Occasionally reads children's picture books aloud with theatrical voices.
Enjoys graphic novels for visual storytelling — recent favorites include 'Persepolis' and 'The Best We Could Do'.
Uses Goodreads to track books and to lend recommendations to friends.
Occasionally writes short technical explainers for the company blog about model interpretability.
Follows indie literary magazines to discover up-and-coming writers.
Avoids clickbait and headline-chasing sites; prefers measured analysis and primary sources.
Watches documentaries on healthcare, urbanism, and food cultures.
Has curated playlists for crafting sessions (lo-fi, acoustic, world music).
Considers film and books as primary ways to explore identity and family stories.
Prefers public radio in the morning and switches to music playlists at night to unwind.
Engages with book clubs (one online, one neighborhood) to discuss themes and craft.
Reads technical papers with a highlighter and a notebook for applied insights.
Values diverse authorship — intentionally reads works by Asian American and mixed-heritage authors.
food_and_drink_preferences: Breakfast staple: coffee (pour-over on weekends, oat milk latte on weekdays) and fruit or an egg-and-veggie scramble.
Enjoys blending Filipino adobo flavors with Korean banchan when entertaining.
Favorite comfort foods: sinigang (tamarind soup) and kimchi jjigae (stew).
Prefers seasonal, locally sourced produce from farmers' markets.
Likes to meal-prep grains and roasted vegetables for weeknight dinners.
Occasional indulgence: artisanal chocolate and a glass of good red wine.
Favorite quick snacks: onigiri (rice balls), fresh mango slices, and roasted seaweed.
Dislikes overly processed microwave meals, except sometimes for convenience on busy days.
Enjoys hosting potlucks where friends bring multicultural dishes.
Prefers tea varieties: jasmine, hojicha, and occasional matcha baked goods.
Has a list of neighborhood cafés: one for working (strong Wi-Fi, quiet), one for catching up with friends (cozy, pastries), and one for weekend family brunches (kid-friendly).
Favors home-cooked meals for nutrition control for the child but maintains a rotation of reliable takeout places.
Likes trying new cuisines but evaluates on balance of kid-friendliness and spice level.
Cooks large batches on weekends and freezes portions for midweek ease.
Is careful about food allergies in social settings — carries a pocket card listing her child's mild tree-nut sensitivity.
Uses fermentation techniques (kimchi, lacto-fermented pickles) as a hobby and for flavor exploration.
Prefers reusable containers and sustainable packaging when ordering takeout.
Keeps a small herb garden on the balcony: cilantro, basil, Thai chiles, and parsley.
Occasionally bakes sourdough and enjoys the ritual of feeding the starter.
Has a few go-to comfort desserts: leche flan and Korean hotteok at street-food stalls.

beliefs: Quality public education is a cornerstone of equitable opportunity.
Health care should be accessible; technology can help but must be regulated to avoid harm.
Data and algorithms can create value but have to be audited for fairness and bias.
Family stories and language matter — preserving Tagalog and Korean phrases in the household is important.
Work is meaningful when it improves someone else's life; metrics alone are insufficient.
Privacy is a human right; companies must be transparent about data use.
People should be judged by contribution and character, not pedigree.
Representation in tech matters: product teams should reflect the users they build for.
Small acts of stewardship (mending clothes, composting) compound to reduce waste.
Lifelong learning keeps skills current and mind engaged.
Therapy is a practical tool for maintaining mental health and should be destigmatized.
Parenting is a mixture of intentional practice and learning from mistakes.
Money is a tool for security and freedom, not a status marker.
Community care networks (neighbors, school groups) are crucial in dense urban settings.
Being multiracial/ multicultural is a strength and a source of occasional identity complexity.
Homeownership can be a stabilizing force but is not the only path to security — renting can be strategic.
Remote and hybrid work should be accessible for parents; flexibility increases retention and wellbeing.
Tech companies must be accountable to public good when products affect health outcomes.
Mentorship and sponsorship are distinct; both are necessary to advance underrepresented talent.
Practical skills (cooking, sewing, basic carpentry) increase resilience and reduce reliance on consumer culture.
Civic engagement (voting, attending school board meetings) matters for neighborhood quality of life.
Regulation lags technology; engineers have a responsibility to anticipate social impacts.
Cultural celebrations and food are primary ways families maintain intergenerational ties.
Children do better when routines are stable but flexibility is modeled by caregivers.
Good UX design in health tools reduces clinician burden and improves adoption.
Being explicit about consent and data lineage improves trust with users.
Learning from mistakes publicly (in a measured way) fosters psychological safety in teams.
Diversity of thought leads to more robust problem-solving than homogeneous teams.
Skepticism is healthy when paired with curiosity — ask 'why' and 'how' before 'if.'
Travel broadens perspective but deep local connections shape daily meaning.
Science and art complement each other — both are ways to explore and make sense of the world.
Climate change is an urgent systemic issue; personal action must be paired with policy change.
Affordable childcare is central to economic mobility for families.
Debt can be a strategic tool when used for investment (education, home) but must be managed responsibly.
Interoperability and open standards in healthcare data reduce friction and duplication of effort.
Cultural humility is more practical than performative multiculturalism.
AI literacy should be part of general education so citizens can engage meaningfully with policy.
Small businesses and local crafts contribute to neighborhood vibrancy and deserve support.
skills: Advanced applied machine learning: supervised learning, time-series forecasting, and representation learning.
Statistical modeling and causal inference: A/B testing, propensity score methods, and instrumental variables.
Programming: expert in Python (pandas, numpy), R for prototyping, SQL for analytical queries.
Productionizing ML: experience with Airflow, Docker, Kubernetes, CI/CD pipelines and model monitoring.
Cloud platforms: Google Cloud Platform (BigQuery, Vertex AI), familiar with AWS equivalents.
Data engineering fundamentals: ETL design, data quality checks, schema design and lineage documentation.
Visualization and storytelling: Tableau, Data Studio; skilled at translating analytics into non-technical recommendations.
Healthcare compliance: practical understanding of HIPAA, PHI handling, and de-identification best practices.
Leadership and mentoring: managing junior data scientists, giving technical and career guidance.
Cross-functional collaboration: working with product managers, clinicians, designers and engineers.
Technical writing: producing reproducible analyses, runbooks, and model datasheets.
Project management: scoping analytics projects, estimating timelines, and balancing technical debt.
Small woodworking and finishing: joinery basics, sanding, finishing with natural oils.
Sewing and textile repair: pattern alteration, sashiko mending, quilt piecing.
Culinary skills: confident improvisational cook blending multiple cuisines.
Public speaking: comfortable presenting to technical teams and clinical advisory boards.
Mentoring in community programs: volunteer coding tutor experience for middle-school students.
Basic Spanish and conversational Korean and Tagalog phrases for family interactions.
Financial literacy: budgeting, tax basics, retirement planning, and early-stage angel-investing fundamentals.
Conflict resolution: mediates team disagreements using structured feedback and interest-based negotiation.

general: Schedules work blocks and rituals around child-care (school drop-off/pick-up) and deep-focus hours.
Prefers asynchronous communication where possible — uses clear README-style notes on projects.
Starts new projects with a 'good enough' prototype to get early feedback, then iterates.
Keeps a physical notebook for craft ideas and a digital note system (Notion) for work projects.
Tends to over-prepare slides and run through them once before important meetings.
Sends weekly 'what I did / what I'm doing' updates to manager and mentees.
Uses short walking breaks to clear her head during long coding sessions.
Declines social invitations when mental bandwidth is low but follows up with a message or small gift.
Celebrates small wins with family rituals (e.g., homemade dessert after a big release).
Buys thoughtful, useful gifts rather than flashy items — often something handmade or sustainably produced.

morning: Wakes at 6:15 AM on weekdays, checks messages briefly, and prepares coffee (pour-over on weekends).
Does a 20-minute yoga or mobility routine three times a week before breakfast.
Prepares a simple breakfast for the family and packs lunches if needed.
Leaves for work by 8:15 AM (hybrid schedule) — typically two days at home, three days in office.
Listens to a short podcast episode or audiobook on the commute.
workday: Starts with a 30–60 minute deep-work block for modeling or code review in the morning.
Schedules collaborative meetings in a tight block to preserve long uninterrupted focus time.
Has a standing lunch walk with a coworker twice a week to maintain social ties.
Uses the Pomodoro technique during heavy-coding sessions and logs blockers in an issue tracker.
Reviews monitoring dashboards mid-afternoon and checks model drift alerts.
Ends the workday with a short sync to align with product/engineering and summarize outstanding items.
evening: Family dinner around 7 PM when schedules allow; uses dinner as a check-in about everyone's day.
Cleans up kitchen while catching up with spouse; spends 30–45 minutes on a craft or reading before bed.
Does a brief review of the next day's priorities, tucks child into bed, and reads a chapter aloud.
Unplugs screens at least 30 minutes before sleep to relax.
Journals once or twice a week about project learnings or parenting triumphs/struggles.
weekend: Saturday mornings: farmers' market run, woodworking or sewing projects, longer family breakfast.
Afternoons: playdates, park visits, or small outings (museums, neighborhood hikes).
Sunday evenings: batch-cooks meals for the week, does laundry, and preps a simple work plan for Monday.
Allocates 2–4 hours across the weekend for a focused craft project or continuing education (online course module).
Meets once a month with a neighborhood craft circle and once a quarter for a makerspace workshop.

health.physical_health: Generally healthy. Height ~5'5" and naturally active with a stable BMI. No chronic medical conditions. Regular annual physicals and dental checkups.
health.mental_health: Proactively manages mental health — has attended therapy intermittently since early 30s, uses mindfulness apps during high-stress periods, and is comfortable discussing therapy with close friends.
health.medications_and_allergies: No daily medications. Seasonal allergy to tree pollen (managed with OTC antihistamines during peak season). Child has a mild tree-nut sensitivity; Liana avoids serving tree-nut heavy snacks at gatherings.
health.exercise: Combines yoga, weekend hikes, and cycling; aims for 150 minutes of moderate activity per week.
health.sleep: Averages 6.5–7.5 hours of sleep most nights; prioritizes sleep hygiene but occasionally disrupted by child's nighttime needs.
health.vision_and_hearing: Wears contact lenses for mild myopia; regular hearing within normal limits.
health.nutrition: Mostly balanced diet emphasizing vegetables, whole grains and lean proteins; occasional indulgences. Keeps portion control in mind.
health.preventive_care: Up-to-date on vaccinations, dental cleanings, and age-appropriate screenings. Uses a health app to track primary care appointments and vaccinations for the child.
health.injuries_and_history: Minor history of sports-related ankle sprain in late 20s that fully recovered. No major hospitalizations.
health.stress_management: Uses structured to-do lists, short meditation, craft time, and therapy check-ins to manage stress. Practices saying 'no' to optional commitments when bandwidth is low.

relationships.name: Mark Chen (spouse)
relationships.description: Partner and co-parent; software engineer at a mid-sized infrastructure company. They met at a hackathon in their late 20s. They share household responsibilities and parenting. Communication style is collaborative, though they occasionally disagree about screen time rules for the child. They enjoy monthly date nights and cooking together.

relationships.name: Sofia Torres (mother)
relationships.description: Lives in Stockton, emotionally close. Sofia is Filipina-American, an avid home cook who taught Liana many family recipes. Regular Sunday calls and recipe exchanges. Sofia provides childcare help a few times a month.

relationships.name: Ji-won Kim (father)
relationships.description: Korean-American, more reserved but proud. Visits a few times a year; values education and encourages Liana's continued learning. Shares woodworking tips and taught Liana how to use a chisel safely.

relationships.name: Diego Torres (younger brother)
relationships.description: Based in Los Angeles, works in education policy. Close relationship; exchanges books and long chats about civic issues. Occasionally helps with home improvement projects remotely.

relationships.name: Nina Park (best friend)
relationships.description: Met in graduate school; now a pediatric nurse. They co-parent playdates and slide into emotional check-ins easily. Trust is high and they trade parenting hacks and craft supplies.

relationships.name: Two junior data scientists (mentees)
relationships.description: Direct reports/mentees at work. Liana meets them weekly for technical coaching, career advice, and project planning. Sponsors one for internal promotion when ready.

relationships.name: Local makerspace collective
relationships.description: Casual acquaintances and collaborators who support Liana's woodworking and finishing projects; share tools and occasional group projects.

relationships.name: Clinical advisory board contacts
relationships.description: Professional network of clinicians and product partners who consult with her team on model deployment and patient-facing workflow design.

relationships.name: Neighbor 'book club' group
relationships.description: Small group of parents who meet monthly to discuss literature and swap childcare advice; social lifeline for neighborhood connections.

other_facts: Full name reflects mixed heritage: Torres (maternal family name rooted in Filipino/Spanish ancestry) and Kim (paternal Korean name). Grew up hearing Tagalog, some Spanish phrases, and Korean in different family contexts.
Grew up in a diverse Bay Area suburb; early exposure to multiple languages made her naturally code-switch between English, Tagalog and occasional Korean set phrases.
As a child, loved taking apart small appliances to understand how they worked; her parents encouraged curiosity but insisted on safety.
Won a regional science fair in high school for a project on sensor-based soil moisture detection for small gardens.
Chosen major in computer science after a college introductory course where she found joy in solving real problems with code.
During undergrad, interned at a health-tech lab where she first saw how analytics could affect patient outcomes — this anchored her later career choices.
Took a gap year between undergrad and grad school to travel through Southeast Asia and South Korea, visiting relatives and practicing language skills.
Her master's thesis focused on interpretability techniques for time-series models applied to wearable health-monitoring data.
Spent a summer building a nonprofit's first basic analytics pipeline during grad school, which taught her how to operate with limited resources.
First full-time job was as a data analyst at a small patient-engagement startup; learned to wear many hats and document processes clearly.
Left two jobs intentionally: once to pursue the M.S., and once to transition from ad-tech to health-tech for mission alignment.
Has presented at regional ML conferences on fairness evaluation in clinical risk models and at local maker fairs on combining textiles with simple woodworking.
Keeps an old sketchbook that contains both craft patterns and early data-model diagrams — sees those practices as part of the same design continuum.
Has a small tattoo on her inner wrist: a simple wave symbolizing continuity and family ties, discussed openly with close friends but not publicized at work.
Regularly donates outgrown children's clothing to a neighborhood charity and organizes a seasonal swap among families to reduce waste.
Maintains a modest emergency fund covering 6–9 months of expenses and contributes to 401(k) and an HSA for tax-advantaged healthcare savings.
Has experimented with part-time freelance analytics work, but values the stability and compliance structure of her current employer.
Was a teaching assistant in an undergraduate data science class, where she found joy in explaining core concepts accessibly.
Has had one close call with imposter syndrome early in career; addressed it through mentorship, incremental exposure and reminding herself of evidence of competence.
Her child's first set of plush toys were handmade by Liana and gifted to family members to strengthen connection to cultural stories.
Enjoys photographing textures (wood grain, fabric weave) and uses these images as backgrounds for her digital notes and mood boards.
Maintains a tiny balcony garden that taught her patience and seasonal planning; uses herbs in daily cooking and teaches the child about plant care.
Learns miniature guitar chords and sings children's songs in Tagalog and Korean during bedtime to preserve languages and make routines soothing.
Has a recurring dream about building a community makerspace focused on bridging tech and craft for youth from underrepresented neighborhoods.
Used to run 5Ks in her late 20s and considers getting back into casual racing as a mid-term goal for fitness and charity fundraising.
Is slightly obsessive about labeling storage bins and backing up photos regularly; has automated backups for work artifacts and personal media.
Prefers small, meaningful celebrations (handwritten notes, favorite meal) over large parties for birthdays and milestones.
Was once part of a small multi-ethnic improv group — it improved her communication skills and ability to think quickly in meetings.
Is not religious in a doctrinal sense but values ritual and community gatherings around cultural holidays (Lunar New Year, Simbang Gabi/Christmas traditions).
Keeps a memory box with handwritten notes from family and friends that she revisits when making difficult decisions.
Has an old voicemail from her grandmother in Tagalog that she occasionally listens to for comfort and to practice pronunciation.
Has a ritual of taking a photo of completed craft projects next to a small plant to document scale and finish for her portfolio.
Has been approached by local schools to run a short workshop combining basic coding concepts and craft to spark interest in STEM among young girls.
Once turned down a promotion because it would have required long, unpredictable travel and would have strained family routines — later negotiated a different role with growth opportunities.
Believes in leaving projects in better order than she found them; volunteers on cross-team documentation sprints at work.
Has a favorite childhood recipe (banana cue with a touch of cinnamon) that she now adapts into quick after-school snacks.
Values grandparents' stories and intentionally records them during visits to preserve family history.
Enjoys occasional microadventures: one-day backpacking trips or exploring a new BART station neighborhood with no particular itinerary.
Has a small, curated set of kitchen knives she uses for both precision cooking and teaching safe skills to her child as they grow.
Keeps an informal 'rules of the workshop' list at her makerspace station emphasizing safety, tool return, and friendly collaboration.
Has a habit of writing a short 'lessons learned' note after each major work project to capture institutional memory and personal growth.
Is often asked to bake for neighborhood events and takes pride in crafting small, culturally blended baked goods that everyone can enjoy.
